Assuming each class is a coherent group (e.g. Gaussian), semi-supervised machine learning predicts decision boundary shift. [Castelli & Cover 96; Ratsaby & Venkatesh 95; Nigam et al. 00]
Do we humans shift decision boundary too?

Observation 1: Unlabeled data affects decision boundary
test1, all test2, Lsubjects test2, Rsubjects
after labeled data (test-1): x = 0.11 after labeled and unlabeled data (test-2): L-subjects x = 0.10, R-subjects x = 0.48

Observation 2: Reaction time reflects boundary shift
test1, all test2, Lsubjects test2, Rsubjects
Longer reaction time closer to decision boundary Test-2 overall faster, familiarity with experiment
L-, R-reaction time further support decision boundary shift
Zhu, Rogers, Qian, Kalish (Wisconsin) Human Semi-Supervised Learning AAAI 2007 14 / 20
Observation 2: Reaction time reflects boundary shift
test1, all test2, Lsubjects test2, Rsubjects
Longer reaction time closer to decision boundary Test-2 overall faster, familiarity with experiment
L-, R-reaction time further support decision boundary shift
Zhu, Rogers, Qian, Kalish (Wisconsin) Human Semi-Supervised Learning AAAI 2007 14 / 20
We can explain the human experiment with a 2-component Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM).
wk Uniform[0, 1], k N(0, ), 2k Inv 2(, s2), k = 1, 2
We fit the GMM with the Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm on blocks 1,2 vs. on all blocks.
Zhu, Rogers, Qian, Kalish (Wisconsin) Human Semi-Supervised Learning AAAI 2007 15 / 20

EM Maximize the objective ( 1 weight on unlabeled example)
E-step qi(k) wkN(xi; k, 2k), i = l + 1, . . . , n; k = 1, 2
Zhu, Rogers, Qian, Kalish (Wisconsin) Human Semi-Supervised Learning AAAI 2007 16 / 20
The GMM predicts the decision boundary shift:
Zhu, Rogers, Qian, Kalish (Wisconsin) Human Semi-Supervised Learning AAAI 2007 17 / 20
Unlabeled data seem to worth less than labeled data ( = 0.06)
Zhu, Rogers, Qian, Kalish (Wisconsin) Human Semi-Supervised Learning AAAI 2007 18 / 20
The GMM also explains reaction time:
t = aH(x) + b, H(x) the entropy of label prediction
Zhu, Rogers, Qian, Kalish (Wisconsin) Human Semi-Supervised Learning AAAI 2007 19 / 20
Humans and machines both perform semi-supervised learning.
Co-training, manifold regularization, S3VMs, etc. in humans should be explored.
Further study may lead to new learning algorithms.
Zhu, Rogers, Qian, Kalish (Wisconsin) Human Semi-Supervised Learning AAAI 2007 20 / 20
Humans and machines both perform semi-supervised learning.
Co-training, manifold regularization, S3VMs, etc. in humans should be explored.
Further study may lead to new learning algorithms.
